So is there any other benefit of bringing in implicit conversion, apart from making it easier to write frontend converters?

On the other hand, could we provide the flexibility of building a temporary Relay IR with non-strict dtypes, and then add a pass to insert explicit conversion?

In modern languages like Golang, the implicit cast has been removed. The rational being that through the decades of sw engineering practice implicit casts have caused more grief than provided in convenience. Secondly, the observation that sw code is read many time more than it is written also points to using explicit casts, so that all the information is present in the code being read.

In numerical software, explicit casting is used to implement numerical adapters (re-discretization, float/integer, and encoding conversion), and for high-performance and OS/driver software to access very specific attributes of the number (the frexp functions). The numerical adapter use case is readily present in DL.

Implicit casting requires that you design a type hierarchy with associated conversion rules. However, even simple languages like C have shown that these type hierarchies are difficult to make consistent. With user-defined types, your type hierarchy is unlikely to be complete and/or consistent, and thus you'll create backward compatibility nightmares that will make your implicit casting code not maintainable.  

So, there really isn't a good reason to implement implicit casting in any way, shape, or form.

1. Could you add my testcase? This example still crash.

```pyhton
def test_tuple_arg():                                             
    shape = (10, 10)                                              
    dtype = 'float32'                                             
    t = relay.TensorType(shape, dtype)                            
    x = relay.var("x", t)                                         
    y = relay.var("y", t)                                         
    tup = relay.var('tup', relay.TupleType([t, t]))               
    func = relay.Function([tup], relay.TupleGetItem(tup, 0))      
    print(func)                                                   
    back_func = relay.ir_pass.infer_type(gradient(func))          
    back_func = relay.ir_pass.dead_code_elimination(back_func)    
    print(back_func)                                             
```

We should suppot tuple as arguments and return value in both first order and high order AD.

2. I found the generated `back_func` is very complicated and sometimes redundant (both in first order case and higher order case) . How do we execute them efficiently? Do we need more optimization passes or do we need a powerful runtime?

With the below code, the result is as expected.
```python
from tvm import relay

x = relay.var("x", shape=(1, 16))
y1 = relay.add(x, relay.const(1.0, "float32"))                                                                                                                                      
y2 = relay.add(x, relay.const(1.0, "float32"))                                                                                                                                      
y = relay.add(y1, y2)
f = relay.Function([x], y)
f = relay.ir_pass.eliminate_common_subexpr(f)
print(f)
```
```
fn (%x: Tensor[(1, 16), float32]) {
  %0 = add(%x, 1f)
  %1 = add(%0, %0)
  %1
}
```
However, when I changed the code a bit as follows, elimination did not work.  Is this not a scope of this PR?
```python
from tvm import relay

x = relay.var("x", shape=(1, 16))
y1 = relay.add(relay.const(1.0, "float32"), x)
y2 = relay.add(relay.const(1.0, "float32"), x)
y = relay.add(y1, y2)
f = relay.Function([x], y)
f = relay.ir_pass.eliminate_common_subexpr(f)
print(f)
```
```
fn (%x: Tensor[(1, 16), float32]) {
  %0 = add(1f, %x)
  %1 = add(1f, %x)
  %2 = add(%0, %1)
  %2          
} 
```

+1

We try to avoid the Python overhead and are always looking at the C++ interfaces. All of our research is centered around new number systems and hardware acceleration and Python is a net negative for any of these use cases.

When customers do ask for a Python interface, we tend to wrap a C++ API of some kind. 

So count us in for a pure C++ interface that removes the Python dependency for both development and production.
#2688 Relay tutorial for Compile MXNet Models

It is possible to write an IR converter which consumes IR built in Python, and outputs C++ source code containing IR building functions in C++, or vise versa. In this way, one could benefit both C++ and Python users at the same time.

@junrushao1994 It depends on how the production pipeline is built. Currently we are moving relay.build_module, relay.frontend.caffe2 and some TOPI to C++ and it should work for Facebook pipeline. If there is an IR convert to convert TOPI directly to C++ it will simplify the problem a lot.

@tqchen @yzhliu @kevinthesun  Thanks. It is merged

Some operators use tuple as arguments (e.g. concatenate) and return value (e.g. split).
We have to use tuple because we don't know the number of arguments.

I am happy to leave it to the next PR, but this feature is necessary.

It is used to prevent overflow in `np.exp`.
You can try
```python
import numpy as np
np.exp(1/(1e-5))
```
Then you will see the warning.

I think having C++ development flow is great and I support the proposal.

In the meanwhile, we will keep the "python first" principle for ease of prototyping and development, so developers will be able to develop in both C++ and python. Note that having python component in compiler does not harm the fact that we can have a clean multi-language deployment.
Thanks I tested two tutorials locally. After minor typo fix and CI, I can merge this

I did the autotuning (AutoTVM with winograd from TVM master) a while ago. I'm going to redo it to get more up-to-date numbers. NNPACK has two implementations for convolution with winograd transform, wt8x8 and wt8x8_fp16. The fp16 implementation is usually the 20% - 30% faster than the fp32 version. On ARM CPUs with fp16 compute support (only Cortex-A76 I believe), NNPACK would run the microkernel with fp16 compute. On other ARM CPUs with fp16 support but not fp16 compute, NNPACK uses fp16 for intermediate storage only (eg. transformed input and kernel, see https://github.com/Maratyszcza/NNPACK/blob/master/src/init.c#L469-L491). It'll be hard to beat NNPACK without fp16.

These two commits need to land together because pylint expectation w.r.t indentation in this particular case changed somewhere between 1.9.6 and 2.2.2.  The old pylint gripes about the new layout and the new pylint gripes about he old layout....

@tqchen  I think this PR is self consistent, it fails in CI because the layout change necessary for pylint 2.2.2 is applied which fails for the current CI pylint==1.9.2  I had hoped that CI would pick up the change to Dockerfile.ci_lint automatically and install the new pylint, apparently that does not happen.  When changes are made to the Dockerfile(s) and their dependent install scripts, how do the CI docker images get rebuilt?
Thanks @SiNZeRo this is merged.

The docker files get built and updated manually in a periodical way, so that images can be cached and reused. Please keep the change to be only the DOCKER script.

It is unfortunate to see that pylint gives non-backward compatible checks. We might need to find a way to get the files consistent to both pylint versions

Can you try to consolidate the following PR into one set of DOCKER changes?

- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2697
- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2699
- https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2700

Thanks
Given that pylint might still be used in some of the demo env ```demo-cpu```, I recommend to just keep it as it is.

OK, after second thought. I think it is fine to merge the change in(remove pylint) if you can consolidate to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/2698
